channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: New President in Sri Lanka Puts China’s Plans in Check
item.description: President Mahinda Rajapaksa was voted out of office in a startling upset, throwing Sri Lanka’s growing alliance with China into question.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Sri Lanka’s new prime minister has said he will cancel a $1.5 billion “port city” being built by China on the waterfront in Colombo, the capital.

item.title: Days of Sirens, Fear and Blood: ‘France Is Turned Upside Down’
item.description: Friday was a day, like the previous two, of violence in and around Paris, one that ended with France unsure whether this drama is now truly over or a predictor of more cultural, religious and political violence to come.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: People on Avenue Joffre during a hostage episode in Paris on Friday.

item.title: Charlie Hebdo Suspects Dead in Raid; Hostage Taker in Paris Is Also Killed
item.description: The police killed the suspects in Wednesday’s massacre and freed their hostage, officials said. A simultaneous raid on a Paris market freed at least some of the hostages held there, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Hostages were evacuated from a kosher grocery store in eastern Paris on Friday.

item.title: Extremists Harming Islam, Leader of Hezbollah Says
item.description: Hassan Nasrallah said in a televised address that extremists’ beheadings and massacres hurt the Prophet Muhammad more than mocking him in books, films or drawings.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Why Reams of Intelligence Did Not Thwart the Attacks
item.description: The double hostage dramas, two days after the deadly assault on a newspaper that had been targeted by Islamist militants, compounded the crisis.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Court Could Move Quickly on Israeli-Palestinian Case
item.description: The International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor can immediately start a preliminary examination of war crimes allegations stemming from the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Reaching Outside C.I.A., Obama Calls on Treasury Official to Become Agency’s No. 2
item.description: President Obama has chosen David S. Cohen, who has directed the effort to cut off funding of the Islamic State and impose economic sanctions on Syria, Russia and Iran, to become the C.I.A.’s deputy director.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Leftists Retract Their Claim About an Attack
item.description: A Marxist extremist group that took responsibility for a suicide bombing in Istanbul this week retracted its claim on Friday, saying that it had made a mistake.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Separatists Intensify Attacks on Army Posts
item.description: At least six Ukrainian soldiers have been killed in more than two days of fighting as separatists intensified shelling of government positions ahead of peace talks expected in the coming week, Ukrainian military officials said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Julio Scherer García, Influential Mexican Journalist and Political Watchdog, Dies at 88
item.description: Mr. Scherer, the founder of the investigative magazine Proceso, created a school of critical journalism that unmasked Mexico’s political corruption and helped lay the groundwork for the country’s democratic transition.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Julio Scherer García in 1976, the year he founded the magazine Proceso.

item.title: Dozens Said to Have Died in Boko Haram Attack
item.description: Refugees in northeast Nigeria described a days-long rampage of shooting, looting and arson by the Islamist terror group.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: News: Latest Updates From France
item.description: Times reporters and editors are providing live updates following two hostage standoffs in France on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Police officers at a check point outside Longpont, France.

item.title: Life Sentence for British Cleric Who Helped Plan 1998 Kidnappings in Yemen
item.description: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, 56, a former imam in North London, had been convicted of 11 terrorism-related charges, including helping to orchestrate the violent 1998 kidnappings of 16 tourists in Yemen.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:description: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, a former imam at the Finsbury Park mosque in North London.

item.title: Saudis Begin Public Caning To Punish A Blogger
item.description: Raif Badawi was sentenced to 1,000 blows, 10 years in prison and a fine for starting a website critical of the country’s religious establishment.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Blast Kills at Least 7 People at Mosque in Pakistan
item.description: Witnesses said that a suicide bomber detonated his explosives outside a Shiite mosque in Rawalpindi, near Pakistan’s capital.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: The Uphill Push to Save a Bike-Share Pioneer
item.description: A Canadian investor takes a chance on a pace-setting system that lost its way.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Graham Hughes for The New York Times
item.media:description: Montreal’s bike-sharing system, considered one of the most innovative, ended up costing the city $25 million.

item.title: Israelis Link Attacks to Their Own Struggles
item.description: For many Israelis, any terrorism by Islamic extremists bolsters the view that their conflict with the Palestinians is part of a larger clash of civilizations.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, right, with Patrick Maisonnave, the French ambassador to Israel, in Jerusalem on Friday.

item.title: Storm Adds to Misery of Gaza’s Most Vulnerable
item.description: A baby in Gaza, where thousands of residents’ homes were destroyed or damaged last summer, was among the cold weather’s victims.
item.dc:creator: By MAJD AL WAHEIDI and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Palestinians gathered around a fire Friday in a damaged building in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, hit by heavy rain and winds.

item.title: In Africa, a Decline in New Ebola Cases Complicates Vaccine Development
item.description: Clinical trials in Africa are being pushed by a sense of urgency as fewer new cases occur, making it more difficult to determine how effective the drugs are.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW POLLACK
item.media:description: Marie-Paule Kieny, World Health Organization (WHO) Assistant Director General, gives a press conference on possible vaccines against the deadly Ebola virus.

item.title: World Briefing: European Official Criticizes Russian Law Banning Transgender Drivers
item.description: The Council of Europe’s human rights commissioner, Nils Muiznieks, called the new law “ridiculous.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
